Award.AwardTitle: The implications of micro-habitat architecture for soil microbial community structure and function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soil health refers to the capacity of soil to sustain life. It is a topic of great scientific and societal importance. Healthy soils have hordes of tiny, beneficial microorganisms that access and recycle the building blocks of life, including nutrients and carbon, and make them available to the next generation of plants. Beneficial soil microorganisms form intricate relationships with plants, supporting crop growth and productivity. Although they comprise some of the most biologically diverse communities on Earth, many details regarding the ways which microorganisms help maintain soil health and promote plant growth remain mysterious. For example, how do microbial communities cope with variations in the water and chemical content of soil, which can change drastically over small distances? This research project will use state-of-the-art methods and recently developed x-ray technology to examine soil micro-scale properties including the number and size of soil pores, pH, and nutrient and carbon quality and availability. These measurements will be coupled with high through-put genome sequencing to examine the impact of these properties on microbial diversity and soil health. This project will serve national interests through advancing fundamental knowledge about the roles that microorganisms play to support soil health, food security and agriculture. The project will also advance the field of soil ecosystem science, and will support education and workforce training through authentic laboratory research opportunities for undergraduates.

The relationship between spatial heterogeneity of soil micro-habitats and microbial diversity will be investigated by dissecting precise physical and chemical micro-environmental variables and the structure and function of their associated microorganisms. The research will determine associations between microorganisms (bacteria and archaea) and micro-environmental variables as a function of soil associations with plants (specifically the microscale distribution of plant-derived carbon in rhizosphere versus bulk soils); and identify the micro-environmental characteristics responsible for suitability of distinct micro-habitats to certain microbial groups. This research offers a fundamentally new approach of combining synchrotron-based X-ray computed micro-tomography information with microbial metagenomics to achieve an improved understanding of the role that physical micro-environmental conditions play in determining compositional and functional diversity of soil microbial communities. This study will pioneer quantitative, combined analysis of key elements important for microbial functioning, including the architecture and characteristics of soil pores, their relationship to micro-biogeographic patterns in microbial structure, and spatial micro-biogeographic patterns that emerge given associations with plant roots. One unique feature of the project is that observed spatial patterns of micro-habitats will be studied with specific reference to local characteristics of soil pores ("geo-referencing"), which are the avenues enabling air, water, and nutrient fluxes and soil microbial migration. Broader impacts will include potential benefits to agriculture, forestry and food security, as well as multidisciplinary undergraduate research training via internships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit
Soil health is the capacity of soil to function as an ecosystem that sustains life. Understanding the mechanisms that determine soil health is of great importance, but there are many knowledge gaps. It is known that soil microorganisms are critical contributors to soil health because they recycle carbon and nutrients, and make these resources available to larger organisms in the food web. It is also known that soil microbiota form intimate relationships with plants and can support crop health and growth. However, soil microbial communities are among the most diverse and complex known, and there are many knowledge gaps regarding the important roles that microbes play generally for soil health and more specifically to benefit plants. For example, soils can exhibit many drastic physical and chemical changes over very small distances (e.g., in texture, particle size, and resource availability and quality), and it is not well understood how these micro-scale spatial changes influence microbial community diversity or functions. The micro-scale spatial structure of soil is expected to impact the diversity and functions of soil microbiota, which is expected to have consequences for soil health.

This research improved understanding of how micro-scale soil spatial structure determines microbial diversity and function. The major goal of the project was to determine associations between microorganisms (bacteria and archaea) and chemical and physical qualities of soil particles in the rhizosphere of plants. We quantified the chemical and physical properties of rhizosphere soil particles and assessed their relationships to microbial groups that contribute to biogeochemical cycling, with a focus on the ammonia oxidizing members of the nitrogen cycle. These microbes perform the first, and often-rate-limiting, step of nitrification when they convert ammonia to nitrite. Nitrification is an important process because it can release the potent greenhouse gas nitrous oxide, which contributes to global warming and is of particular concern in agriculture.

We collected agricultural soils from two sites in Michigan, planted them with the legume common bean to create a rhizosphere environment that enabled plant-soil-microbiome feedback, and then removed and fractionated the soils into seven discrete pools along a gradient of different particle sizes (ranges < 0.05 to 2 mm). We then used these particle size fractions to perform analyses of their chemical and physical properties and of their microbiome. We considered all the detectable members of the microbiome as well as the members of the functional guild of ammonia oxidizers, which include groups of both bacteria and archaea. We found that, while soil particle size has a clear impact on microbiome structure, there is not a one-size-fits-all relationship between soil particle size and ammonia oxidizing guild structure, diversity, or abundances across the different soils. We also found that the relationship between soil particle size and ammonia oxidizing community diversity, abundance, and structure can be different for bacteria and archaea, even within the same soil. Notably, these different patterns were not apparently attributable to differences in measured chemistry in the different particle fractions. These results suggest that site-specific strategies that consider soil physical and chemical structure may be important for managing bacterial and archaeal contributions to ammonia oxidation and mitigating their effects on nitrous oxide release and the nitrogen cycle of agricultural soils, but further work is needed.

Broader Impacts
Over the total award period, we have contributed to the scientific workforce development and training of 13 individuals:  five PhD students (three female), three post-docs, four undergraduates (two female), and one technician (female).  These trainees developed discipline-specific skills in microbiology, plant-microbe interactions, soil sciences, instrumentation, and molecular biology.  They also developed transferrable skills in written and oral communication, mentoring, computing, multivariate statistics, data science, and teamwork and collaboration.


This award supported the development of new learning materials to enhance understanding and appreciation of the importance of plant-microbiome interactions for an upper-level undergraduate microbial ecology course offered at Michigan State University.


This award contributed to 5 peer-reviewed manuscripts that were published in scientific journals, with one more manuscript in preparation.  It also supported several undergraduate research presentations.


This work has implications for understanding microbial contributions to soil health and sustainable agriculture, and more specifically, for understanding the soil properties that can promote microbial ammonia oxidation in agricultural soils.
